bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, April 30, [1943]

div1.p: Kean comments on Wood's manuscript. He believes that Reed or Lazear would have volunteered to be inoculated before Carroll. Kean suggests that Lazear believed in the mosquito theory and was the first to try it on himself.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, April 30, [1943]
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
April 30, 1943
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
I was thinking this morning
of you and was looking up my
file to see how long it had been
since I heard from you when
the mail came with your good
letter of the 27th and the photographs
I am so pleased to get that of the
family group. My first remark
to Mrs Kean was I am so glad to
see your mother there and my
next was how young they look!
Your mother with her dark hair looks
as if she might be the mother of that
pretty girl standing behind Mrs Hench
instead of the grandmother.

It was interesting to note that the
mother and your mother had their
eyes on the baby John Bixler, and
Susan was so proud to be holding
him.

I am delighted that you will have
that trip to the West Coast and
will see Mrs Lazear and Gen.
Truby. I will be keen to know your
impression of the former. Her repu-
tation is that of being a difficult
person, but perhaps you with your
cordial and tactful approach will
get her to thaw out. I hope Truby
will have his book by that time. I
am hoping to see it in print too &
with the illustrations. I am not such
a picture sharp as you and Truby are
3
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
but that like music is a deficiency
of mine. Mrs Laura Wood sent me
her book on April 12 and I have
read it through, tho it has been a busy
time for me. I think it is excellent.
There are a few errors of course but
they are of details which are quite
unimportant. I wrote her it was a
bold procedure and a risky one
to take the dramatic method and
have the dramatis personae do the
talking and tell the story. But she
has gotten away with it very well.
Of course you and I know that in
the conference of the Board about Aug
1st about experimenting on men, it would
be Reed or Lazear, not Carroll, who
AC
K
4
would say that the members of the
Board should be the first to try it.
I think that Lazear who believed in
the mosquito theory was the first to try
it on himself and Carroll who did
not believe in it was next and was
the first case. I remember that he
complained somewhat bitterly that
Lazear had given him the whole
works. She makes Carroll propose
that the members should try it &
she makes the visit to Finlay come
after this conference. I think it
must have been before. But I
was in New Jersey with my family
at that time and was admiring my
little son a week or two old - you
know about that - Mrs Wood's book
is very readable, and I think is a
permanent and valuable addition to
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
the history of the Y.F. Episode.

I have been very busy what with the
dedication and the difficult question
of invitations and tickets which were
much in demand here. Also inside
of two days I had four gifts of new
books from the authors with very nice
flattering inscriptions in them which
of course required prompt and
carefully written letters of acknowl-
edgement, which showed at least
some knowledge of the contents.
I will get this off now by my
last chance tonight and will
write about the dedication later
